Title.evidence: Virtual Reality in Surgical Training: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: 25 first- and second-year students without prior experience in the procedure were randomly assigned to three groups

Participants.evidence: Conducted at a medical school, 25 first- and second-year students without prior experience in the procedure

Intervention.evidence: randomly assigned to three groups: technique guide control (n = 8), VR group (n = 8), or VR and technique guide group (n = 9)

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial assessed the impact of virtual reality (VR) simulation on the training of medical students

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the successful completion of the procedure, defined as correct placement of the nail and screw, evaluated by a blinded orthopaedic surgeon

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was achieved using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment ensured

Blinding.evidence: evaluated by a blinded orthopaedic surgeon

Number_Randomised.evidence: randomly assigned to three groups: technique guide control (n = 8), VR group (n = 8), or VR and technique guide group (n = 9)

Number_Analysed.evidence: A greater proportion of participants in the VR group (6 of 8) and the VR and technique guide group (7 of 9) completed the procedure

Result_Outcome.evidence: Procedural accuracy was higher in the VR groups, with fewer incorrect steps (3.2 ± 0.1 and 3.1 ± 0.1) than the technique guide group (5.7 ± 0.2; p = 0.02)
